Thanks for the direction to previous postings here; they helped 
alot.  seems to be a lot of mystery around these little tools.  What 
swords had which tool more commonly, when did they first appear, and 
of course for some, what were they really used for.

i now have several avenues of research to persue.

Man, i am really starting to love this hobby!!  Every answer leasds 
to 10 questions ... and the stuff (the real stuff) is super beautiful.

will share any new research.

doug e.
-- In nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com, "Jim Gilbert" <jggilbert@E...> 
wrote:
> Doug,
> I think that the mundane explanation of the use of the kogai is 
probably the correct one.  The shaft/point is for arranging hair and 
the hook at the other end (mimikaki) is for cleaning ears.  The same 
sort of implement exists for women, but often made out of tortoise 
shell or other materials.  I happened to see an extensive display of 
them at the Tokyo National Museum a couple of years ago.  You can 
still buy bags of little wooden mimikaki in Japan -- kind of like Q-
tips, but hard and pointy.
> 
> The umabari or bashin was apparently used for acupuncture and 
perhaps minor surgery on horses.  I was skeptical of the acupuncture 
idea, but apparently it was done.  Tom Helm had more information on 
this the last time the topic came up here, so it'd be worth checking 
the list archives to dig it up.
> 
> I've heard several alternative stories on the use of the kogai, but 
none of them were entirely convincing.  If anyone has good sources, 
evidence or arguments supporting other versions I'd like to hear it.  
Multiple uses are possible.
> Jim
